bestBHT.bht: Saul's use of the Hebrew language is significant, as it is not mentioned in other accounts. The phrase it is hard for thee to kick against the pricks illustrates the futility and harm of resisting divine authority. It conveys the idea that opposing God's will is like an ox kicking against a goad, causing more pain. This proverb, commonly used in Greek literature, emphasizes the inevitable submission to God's plan. Saul's conversion is presented as a struggle against God's will, ultimately leading to his transformation into a follower of Christ.

Henry Alford: in the Hebrew tongue...In ch. ix. we have the fact remarkably preserved by the Hebrew form in the original; in ch. xxii. he was speaking in Hebrew, and the notice was not required.

it is hard for thee to kick against the pricks...The metaphor is derived from oxen at plough or drawing a burden, who, on being pricked with the goad, kick against it, and so cause it to pierce deeper.
See instances, in my Greek Test., of the use of the proverb.
Marvin Vincent: It is hard for thee to kick against the pricks.
Being enraged, I would kick against the goads, a mortal against a God.
If you strike the goads with your fists, you hurt your hands more than the goads.
Philip Schaff: It is hard for thee to kick against the pricks."
On the use of the Hebrew tongue on this solemn occasion, see the Excursus at the end of this chapter.
Archibald T. Robertson: In the Hebrew language (τη Εβραιδ διαλεκτω).
It is hard for thee to kick against the goad (σκληρον σο προς κεντρα λακτιζειν).
Κεντρον means either sting as of bees (II Macc. 14:19) and so of death (1 Corinthians 15:55) or an iron goad in the ploughman's hand as here.
John Gill: And when we were all fallen to the earth,.... Saul, and the men that were with him, for fear of the divine Majesty"
the other narratives only relate Saul's falling to the earth
how this is to be reconciled to their standing speechless
John Wesley: In the Hebrew tongue — St. Paul was not now speaking in Hebrew: when he was, Acts 23:7, he did not add, In the Hebrew tongue. Christ used this tongue both on earth and from heaven.
